channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Australia grapples with how to investigate scientific misconduct
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02669-4

The nation currently allows institutes to investigate cases in-house — but calls to change this are mounting
item.dc:title: Australia grapples with how to investigate scientific misconduct
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: Reply to: Palaeospondylus and the early evolution of gnathostomes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06435-4

Reply to: Palaeospondylus and the early evolution of gnathostomes
item.dc:title: Reply to: Palaeospondylus and the early evolution of gnathostomes
item.dc:creator: Tatsuya Hirasawa
Shigeru Kuratani

item.title: Palaeospondylus and the early evolution of gnathostomes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06434-5

Palaeospondylus and the early evolution of gnathostomes
item.dc:title: Palaeospondylus and the early evolution of gnathostomes
item.dc:creator: Chase Doran Brownstein

item.title: Brain-reading implants turn thoughts into speech
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02683-6

Two studies demonstrate how brain-computer interfaces could help people to communicate, and working out how hot it can get before tropical leaves start to die.
item.dc:title: Brain-reading implants turn thoughts into speech
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: A rainbow of LEDs adorns objects at the stroke of a pen
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02655-w

Ordinary ballpoint pens loaded with conductive inks ‘write’ LEDs onto textiles, packaging and more.
item.dc:title: A rainbow of LEDs adorns objects at the stroke of a pen

item.title: Black hole total recoil
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02653-y

A black hole created by the collision of two parent bodies can rebound at a speed of more than 28,000 kilometres per second.
item.dc:title: Black hole total recoil

item.title: Light-enabled deracemization of cyclopropanes by Al-salen photocatalysis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06407-8

Irradiation of chiral Al-salen complexes with violet light demonstrates efficient deracemization of cyclopropanes, enabling reactivity and enantioselectivity to be regulated simultaneously, negating the requirement for tailored catalyst–substrate recognition motifs.
item.dc:title: Light-enabled deracemization of cyclopropanes by Al-salen photocatalysis
item.dc:creator: Carina Onneken
Tobias Morack
Julia Soika
Olga Sokolova
Niklas Niemeyer
Christian Mück-Lichtenfeld
Constantin G. Daniliuc
Johannes Neugebauer
Ryan Gilmour

item.title: Increased Amazon carbon emissions mainly from decline in law enforcement
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06390-0

Comparison of the carbon balance during 2010–2018 with 2019 and 2020 shows that a decline in law enforcement may have led to an increase in Amazon forest carbon emissions.
item.dc:title: Increased Amazon carbon emissions mainly from decline in law enforcement

item.title: Forced changes in the Pacific Walker circulation over the past millennium
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06447-0

Analysis of a new annually resolved, multi-method, palaeoproxy-derived reconstruction ensemble for the period 1200–2000 suggests that recent variability in the Pacific Walker circulation is unusual but not unprecedented over the past 800 years.
item.dc:title: Forced changes in the Pacific Walker circulation over the past millennium
item.dc:creator: Georgina Falster
Bronwen Konecky
Sloan Coats
Samantha Stevenson

item.title: From target discovery to clinical drug development with human genetics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06388-8

This Review provides a perspective on the development of non-cancer therapies based on human genetics studies and suggests measures that can be taken to streamline the pipeline from initial genetic discovery to approved therapy.
item.dc:title: From target discovery to clinical drug development with human genetics
item.dc:creator: Katerina Trajanoska
Claude Bhérer
Daniel Taliun
Sirui Zhou
J. Brent Richards
Vincent Mooser

item.title: Reef-building corals farm and feed on their photosynthetic symbionts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06442-5

Long-term experiments show that corals acquire dissolved inorganic nitrogen and phosphorus by feeding on symbiont cells, which provide essential nutrients enabling their success in nutrient-poor waters.
item.dc:title: Reef-building corals farm and feed on their photosynthetic symbionts
item.dc:creator: Jörg Wiedenmann
Cecilia D’Angelo
M. Loreto Mardones

Cassandra E. Benkwitt

Or Ben-Zvi

Amatzia Genin

item.title: Proton transport through nanoscale corrugations in two-dimensional crystals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06247-6

A study using high-resolution scanning electrochemical cell microscopy attributes proton permeation through defect-free graphene and hexagonal boron nitride to transport across areas of the structure that are under strain.
item.dc:title: Proton transport through nanoscale corrugations in two-dimensional crystals
item.dc:creator: O. J. Wahab
E. Daviddi

E. Griffin

P. R. Unwin

item.title: The complete sequence of a human Y chromosome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06457-y

We present the complete 62,460,029-base-pair sequence of a human Y chromosome from the HG002 genome (T2T-Y) that corrects multiple errors in GRCh38-Y and adds over 30 million base pairs of sequence to the reference.
item.dc:title: The complete sequence of a human Y chromosome

item.title: Native diversity buffers against severity of non-native tree invasions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06440-7

Analysis combining multiple global tree databases reveals that whether a location is invaded by non-native tree species depends on anthropogenic factors, but the severity of the invasion depends on the native species diversity.
item.dc:title: Native diversity buffers against severity of non-native tree invasions

item.title: A high-performance speech neuroprosthesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06377-x

A speech-to-text brain–computer interface that records spiking activity from intracortical microelectrode arrays enabled an individual who cannot speak intelligibly to achieve 9.1 and 23.8% word error rates on a 50- and 125,000-word vocabulary, respectively.
item.dc:title: A high-performance speech neuroprosthesis
item.dc:creator: Francis R. Willett
Erin M. Kunz
Chaofei Fan
Donald T. Avansino
Guy H. Wilson
Eun Young Choi
Foram Kamdar
Matthew F. Glasser
Leigh R. Hochberg
Shaul Druckmann
Krishna V. Shenoy
Jaimie M. Henderson

item.title: An analog-AI chip for energy-efficient speech recognition and transcription
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06337-5

A low-power chip that runs AI models using analog rather than digital computation shows comparable accuracy on speech-recognition tasks but is more than 14 times as energy efficient.
item.dc:title: An analog-AI chip for energy-efficient speech recognition and transcription
item.dc:creator: S. Ambrogio
P. Narayanan

item.title: Non-cell-autonomous cancer progression from chromosomal instability
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06464-z

Chromosomal instability in cancer is linked to endoplasmic reticulum stress signalling, immune suppression and metastasis, which is mediated by the cGAS–STING pathway, suppression of which can reduce metastasis.
item.dc:title: Non-cell-autonomous cancer progression from chromosomal instability
item.dc:creator: Jun Li
Melissa J. Hubisz

item.title: A high-performance neuroprosthesis for speech decoding and avatar control
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06443-4

A study using high-density surface recordings of the speech cortex in a person with limb and vocal paralysis demonstrates real-time decoding of brain activity into text, speech sounds and orofacial movements.
item.dc:title: A high-performance neuroprosthesis for speech decoding and avatar control
item.dc:creator: Sean L. Metzger
Kaylo T. Littlejohn
Alexander B. Silva

Edward F. Chang

item.title: OPA1 helical structures give perspective to mitochondrial dysfunction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06462-1

Cryo-electron microscopy structures of OPA1, mutations of which are associated with the disease dominant optic atrophy, provide insight into how structural features of OPA1 enable this protein to mediate mitochondrial-membrane fusion and remodelling.
item.dc:title: OPA1 helical structures give perspective to mitochondrial dysfunction
item.dc:creator: Sarah B. Nyenhuis
Xufeng Wu
Marie-Paule Strub
Yang-In Yim
Abigail E. Stanton
Valentina Baena
Zulfeqhar A. Syed
Bertram Canagarajah
John A. Hammer
Jenny E. Hinshaw

item.title: Tropical forests are approaching critical temperature thresholds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06391-z

Ground truthed thermal data from a new NASA satellite combined with experimental warming data from three continents in an empirical model suggests that tropical forests are closer to a high temperature threshold than previously thought.
item.dc:title: Tropical forests are approaching critical temperature thresholds
item.dc:creator: Christopher E. Doughty
Jenna M. Keany
Benjamin C. Wiebe

Joshua B. Fisher

item.title: A global rise in alluvial mining increases sediment load in tropical rivers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06309-9

The assembly and analysis of a 37-year satellite database covering almost 400 mining districts in 49 countries shows that a rise in river mineral mining has substantially increased riverine sediment load in tropical rivers worldwide.
item.dc:title: A global rise in alluvial mining increases sediment load in tropical rivers
item.dc:creator: Evan N. Dethier
Miles Silman
Jimena Díaz Leiva
Sarra Alqahtani
Luis E. Fernandez

Francis J. Magilligan
Carl E. Renshaw
David A. Lutz

item.title: Landscape-scale benefits of protected areas for tropical biodiversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06410-z

Protected areas across mega-diverse Southeast Asia are associated with elevated vertebrate biodiversity inside their boundaries and in surrounding areas.
item.dc:title: Landscape-scale benefits of protected areas for tropical biodiversity
item.dc:creator: Jedediah F. Brodie
Jayasilan Mohd-Azlan
Cheng Chen

item.title: Structural mechanism of mitochondrial membrane remodelling by human OPA1
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06441-6

Human OPA1 embeds itself into cardiolipin-containing membranes through a lipid-binding paddle domain, and OPA1 oligomerization through multiple assembly interfaces promotes the helical assembly of a flexible OPA1 lattice on the membrane, driving mitochondrial fusion in cells.
item.dc:title: Structural mechanism of mitochondrial membrane remodelling by human OPA1
item.dc:creator: Alexander von der Malsburg
Gracie M. Sapp

Adam Frost
Halil Aydin

item.title: Assembly of 43 human Y chromosomes reveals extensive complexity and variation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06425-6

De novo assemblies of 43 Y chromosomes spanning 182,900 years of human evolution reveal considerable diversity in the size and structure of the human Y chromosome.
item.dc:title: Assembly of 43 human Y chromosomes reveals extensive complexity and variation
item.dc:creator: Pille Hallast

item.title: Increased hyaluronan by naked mole-rat Has2 improves healthspan in mice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06463-0

Mice overexpressing Has2 from the naked mole-rat showed an increase in hyaluronan levels in several tissues, and a lower incidence of spontaneous and induced cancer, attenuated inflammation through several pathways, extended lifespan and improved healthspan.
item.dc:title: Increased hyaluronan by naked mole-rat Has2 improves healthspan in mice
item.dc:creator: Zhihui Zhang

item.title: Yes, and
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02643-0

The non-human touch.
item.dc:title: Yes, and
item.dc:creator: Marissa Lingen

item.title: Tackle ever-growing consumption to safeguard sustainability gains
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02596-4

The world is consuming more efficiently, but still using more stuff. More-concerted efforts to change both consumer and producer behaviour are needed.
item.dc:title: Tackle ever-growing consumption to safeguard sustainability gains

item.title: Satellite images show the widespread impact of mining on tropical rivers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02349-3

A careful analysis of satellite images has revealed marked changes in the suspended-sediment concentrations of many rivers around the world. The study links these changes directly to river mining activities in the affected areas.
item.dc:title: Satellite images show the widespread impact of mining on tropical rivers
item.dc:creator: Bryony Walmsley

item.title: India lands on the Moon! Scientists celebrate as Chandrayaan-3 touches down
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02690-7

The craft has performed a technically challenging descent at the lunar south pole.
item.dc:title: India lands on the Moon! Scientists celebrate as Chandrayaan-3 touches down
item.dc:creator: T. V. Padma

item.title: ‘We are killing this ecosystem’: the scientists tracking the Amazon’s fading health
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02599-1

Climate change, deforestation and other human threats are driving therainforest towards a tipping point of sustainability. Researchers are racingto chart the Amazon’s future.
item.dc:title: ‘We are killing this ecosystem’: the scientists tracking the Amazon’s fading health
item.dc:creator: Daniel Grossman

item.title: Scientists who don't speak fluent English get little help from journals, study finds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02529-1

An analysis of hundreds of journals finds limited efforts to accommodate scientists who are not native English speakers.
item.dc:title: Scientists who don't speak fluent English get little help from journals, study finds
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Analog chip paves the way for sustainable AI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02569-7

As the resources required by artificial intelligence increase unsustainably, an analog design provides an energy-efficient alternative to digital computer chips — and one that is ideally suited to neural-network computations.
item.dc:title: Analog chip paves the way for sustainable AI
item.dc:creator: Hechen Wang

item.title: Is there life on Mars? What a cave on Earth can teach us
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02604-7

Seventeen-year-old Zahra Ronizi jump-starts her dream of becoming an astronaut and going to Mars by joining a simulated mission in a Spanish cave as a crew biologist.
item.dc:title: Is there life on Mars? What a cave on Earth can teach us
item.dc:creator: Chris Woolston

item.title: Brain-reading devices allow paralysed people to talk using their thoughts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02682-7

Two studies report considerable improvements in technologies designed to help people with facial paralysis to communicate.
item.dc:title: Brain-reading devices allow paralysed people to talk using their thoughts
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Brain implants that enable speech pass performance milestones
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02546-0

Two brain–computer interfaces have been developed that bring unprecedented capabilities for translating brain signals into sentences — at speeds close to that of normal speech, and with vocabularies exceeding 1,000 words.
item.dc:title: Brain implants that enable speech pass performance milestones
item.dc:creator: Nick F. Ramsey
Nathan E. Crone

item.title: Corals have algal friends for dinner
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02593-7

Biologists have long sought to understand the factors that enable coral reefs to thrive. A careful analysis of nutrient cycling now points to an unexpected food source that helps to sustain corals during food scarcity.
item.dc:title: Corals have algal friends for dinner
item.dc:creator: Virginia M. Weis

item.title: Could a blood test diagnose the cause of kids' fevers?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02624-3

RNA transcripts can discriminate between 18 categories of disease, including common bacteria and viruses as well as rare, potentially life-threatening conditions.
item.dc:title: Could a blood test diagnose the cause of kids' fevers?

item.title: Want a sustainable future? Then look to the world’s cities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02597-3

In a rapidly urbanizing world, what happens in cities matters — and sustainability success stories show what can be achieved when researchers and policymakers work together.
item.dc:title: Want a sustainable future? Then look to the world’s cities

item.title: Leveraging my training in space medicine for technological innovation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02672-9

Shawna Pandya explores entrepreneurial niches to bring virtual-reality medicine to space exploration.
item.dc:title: Leveraging my training in space medicine for technological innovation
item.dc:creator: Lesley Evans Ogden

item.title: Daily briefing: New coronavirus variant BA.2.86 is exceedingly rare
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02675-6

Researchers are racing to determine whether the SARS-CoV-2 variant BA.2.86 will be a global concern — or nothing to worry about. Plus, the Human Brain Project has missed its audacious goal to recreate the brain in a computer and tiny lab-grown organs could crack the mystery of menstruation.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: New coronavirus variant BA.2.86 is exceedingly rare
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Allow patents on AI-generated inventions — for the good of science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02598-2

The current global mishmash of rules on whether innovations made using artificial intelligence are patentable impedes AI-rich fields such as drug discovery.
item.dc:title: Allow patents on AI-generated inventions — for the good of science
item.dc:creator: Ryan Abbott

item.title: Europe spent €600 million to recreate the human brain in a computer. How did it go?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02600-x

The Human Brain Project wraps up in September after a decade. Nature examines its achievements and its troubled past.
item.dc:title: Europe spent €600 million to recreate the human brain in a computer. How did it go?
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.content:encoded:

item.content:encoded:

Now lying forgotten in many a drawer, the modern computer’s handheld predecessors heralded an era of effortless calculation — an innovation 42,000 years in the making.

item.dc:creator: Jeffrey M. Perkel

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02670-x

This year could be the warmest on record — and next year is likely to be even hotter. Plus, Russia’s lander has crashed on the Moon and how to speed up scientific progress.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: July 2023 was the hottest month in recorded history
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Why a highly mutated coronavirus variant has scientists on alert
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02656-9

Research is under way to determine whether the mutation-laden lineage BA.2.86 has the potential for global spread — or whether it is nothing to worry about.
item.dc:title: Why a highly mutated coronavirus variant has scientists on alert

item.title: Russian Moon lander crash — what happened, and what’s next?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02659-6

The Luna 25 mission has ended in failure, raising major questions about the future of Russia’s space program.
item.dc:title: Russian Moon lander crash — what happened, and what’s next?

item.content:encoded:

item.content:encoded:

item.title: Magneto-optics in a van der Waals magnet tuned by self-hybridized polaritons
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06275-2

In the layered magnetic semiconductor CrSBr, emergent light–matter hybrids (polaritons) increase the spectral bandwidth of correlations between the magnetic, electronic and optical properties, enabling largely tunable optical responses to applied magnetic fields and magnons.
